summary: The SAC (Special Agent in Charge) of the FBI's Los Angeles office was a sender of multiple reports concerning John Rosselli's activities and whereabouts in the early 1960s. These reports, primarily teletypes and airtels, were directed to the Director of the FBI and, in some cases, the SAC in Las Vegas. The documents detail Rosselli's travels, associates, and financial transactions, indicating an active FBI interest in monitoring his movements and connections. The reports suggest that the Los Angeles SAC was responsible for gathering and disseminating intelligence on Rosselli's activities within its jurisdiction.
significance: The SAC, Los Angeles's significance in the JFK assassination context stems from their role in monitoring John Rosselli, a figure who has been linked to organized crime and alleged plots related to the assassination. The documents indicate that the FBI, through the Los Angeles SAC, was actively tracking Rosselli's activities in the years leading up to President Kennedy's assassination. The information gathered and disseminated by the SAC, Los Angeles, may be relevant to understanding the extent of the FBI's knowledge of Rosselli's activities and potential involvement in any conspiracies.
